subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
Variant of {{l|mul|稻}}. The component {{l|mul|旧}} is a variant of {{l|mul|臼}}.

The Japanese usage is of reform ({{w|shinjitai}}) nature.

subSections.title: Readings
Compounds
Etymology 1
subSections.text:
{{wp|lang=ja|イネ}} {{wp|Oryza sativa}}
{{ja-kanjitab|いね|yomi=k}} {{IPAfont|⟨i1nai⟩}} → *{{IPAchar|/jinai/}} → *{{IPAchar|/jine/}} → {{IPAchar|/ine/}} From {{inh|ja|ojp|sort=いね|-}}. Possibly from {{inh|ja|jpx-pro|-}} *''jinaC-''Whitman, John (2012). "[https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s12284-011-9080-0 Northeast Asian Linguistic Ecology and the Advent of Rice Agriculture in Korea and Japan], ''Rice'', Volume 4, Issue 3–4, pp 149–158. https://doi.org/10.1007/s12284-011-9080-0 and related to {{m|ja|米|tr=yone||[[husked]] [[rice]]}}. Unknown "-C-" consonantal "stem", reconstructed by Vovin (1998), seems unlikely considering {{IPAfont|[a ~ e]}} vowel alternation: : Compare {{m|ja|藍|tr=awi → ai||[[indigo]]}} from {{m|ja|青|tr=awo||[[blue]]}} + {{m|ja|い|tr=i|pos=emphatic nominative particle}}Thomas Pellard (2013). [https://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/hal-01289288/document Ryukyuan perspectives on the proto-Japonic vowel system]. Frellesvig, Bjarke; Sells, Peter. Japanese/Korean Linguistics 20, CSLI Publications, pp.81–96, 2013. against {{m|ja|白き|tr={{IPAfont|⟨siro1ki1⟩}} → shiroki}} → {{m|ja|白い|tr=shiroi||[[white]]}}. Hamano, S. "Voicing of Obstruents in Old Japanese: Evidence from the Sound-Symbolic Stratum." ''Journal of East Asian Linguistics'' (2000) 9. 3: 207-225. https://doi.org/10.1023/A:1008367619295.

subSections.title: Etymology 2
Derived terms
Etymology 3
subSections.text:
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=irr|sort=しね}}
Often found in compounds. The initial s- either represents [[w:epenthesis|epenthesis]] or, more likely, is a reflex of an older form of the word {{m|ja|稲|tr=ine||[[rice]]}} maintained in fossilized compounds. See also {{m|ja|春雨|tr=harusame||[[spring]] [[rain]]}} and {{m|ja|小雨|tr=kosame||light rain}}.
